questions.text: Hepatitis E is a liver infection caused by the hepatitis E virus (HEV). HEV is found in the stool of an infected person. It is spread when someone unknowingly ingests the virus - even in microscopic amounts. During an epidemic of hepatitis E, fatality is maximum in :
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Pregnant women Hepatitis E:- It is transmitted by fecal-oral route by infected water. A most common cause of Acute viral hepatitis in adults. The most common cause of an epidemic of hepatitis in India in Children is Hepatitis A Hepatitis E: Both IgM anti-HEV and IgG HEV can be detected. Maximum fatality is seen in pregnant women in cases of Hepatitis E infection by causing fulminant hepatitis.

questions.correct_answer: A. 10% of patients with acute HCV infection progress to chronic hepatitis C
questions.explanation:
Solution:

10% of patients with acute HCV infection progress to chronic hepatitis C The given clinical scenario suggests hepatitis C infection. About 85-90% of patients with acute HCV infection progress to chronic hepatitis. Although many patients with chronic hepatitis C have no symptoms, cirrhosis may develop in as many as 20% within 10–20 years of acute illness. The advanced age of acquisition, long duration of infection, immunosuppression, coexisting excessive alcohol use, concomitant hepatic steatosis, other hepatitis virus infection, or HIV co-infection may influence the progression of chronic hepatitis C .

Patients with jaundice, those with HCV genotype 1, women with earlier infection, lower levels of HCV RNA, HBV co-infection, and absence of current injection-drug use are more likely to recover from acute hepatitis C without treatment. Option: C. HCV RNA is the standard gold test for hepatitis C. HCV RNA is detected by Target amplification. Option: D. Cytotoxic chemotherapy can lead to the reactivation of chronic hepatitis C as well, and anti-TNF-α therapy can lead to the reactivation of both hepatitis B and C.

questions.text: A health care worker who had an accidental needle prick injury two months back now complaints of anorexia, nausea, and vomiting. Which of the following test is the gold standard and earliest test to become positive for detecting Hepatitis C virus?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

HCV RNA Assays for HCV RNA are the most sensitive tests (sensitivity as low as 5 IU/mL) for HCV infection and represent the “gold standard” in establishing a diagnosis of hepatitis C. HCV RNA can be detected even before the acute elevation of aminotransferase activity and before the appearance of anti-HCV in patients with acute hepatitis C. HCV RNA remains detectable Indefinitely, in patients with chronic hepatitis and inactive carriers. If anti-HCV is negative, a diagnosis can be supported by the detection of HCV RNA. HCV RNA is detected by target amplification in PCR. Determination of HCV RNA level is not a reliable marker of disease severity or prognosis but helps predict relative responsiveness to antiviral therapy.

Option: B. Serum bilirubin is nonspecific; both direct and indirect bilirubin is raised. ALT> AST in viral hepatitis. Option: D. In patients with hepatitis C, an episodic pattern of aminotransferase elevation is common.

questions.text: 27-year-old pregnant woman patient was diagnosed positive with hepatitis C 6 months back. The treatment options available for this patient are all except:

Solution:

Ribavirin Ribavirin is contraindicated during pregnancy . Therefore, any regimen including ribavirin should not be used. Sofosbuvir; sofosbuvir + ledipasvir; and paritaprevir/ritonavir, ombitasvir, and dasabuvir are classified as pregnancy category B . These therapies are not indicated routinely in pregnancy and should be used cautiously only if the benefit outweighs the risk.

questions.text: Which of the following is TRUE about immunity that appears to develop commonly after acute HCV infection?
questions.correct_answer: A. Neither heterologous nor homologous immunity
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Neither heterologous nor homologous immunity The divergence of HCV isolates within a genotype or subtype and within the same host may vary insufficiently to define a distinct genotype; these intra-genotypic differences are referred to as quasispecies and differ in sequence homology by only a few percent. The genotypic and quasispecies diversity of HCV, resulting from its high mutation rate, interferes with effective humoral immunity. Neutralizing antibodies to HCV have been demonstrated, but they tend to be short-lived. HCV infection does not induce lasting immunity against reinfection with different virus isolates or even the same virus isolate. Thus, neither heterologous nor homologous immunity appears to develop commonly after acute HCV infection.
